examples: a sudden splendor counterchanged the level lake with diamond-plots of dark and bright

noun.description: Change that is equivalent in degree but opposite in effect to a previous change.
examples: to all change there must be counterchange

noun.description: Patterning in which a dark motif on a light ground alternates with the same motif light on a dark ground.

origin: Late Middle English (as a heraldic term): from French contrechanger, from contre (expressing substitution) + changer to change.
